{{Other uses|Sacramentum (disambiguation)}}
In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]] and [[Roman law|law]], the '''''sacramentum''''' was an [[oath]] or vow that rendered the swearer ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#sacer|sacer]],'' "given to the gods," in the negative sense if he violated it.<ref>[[Jörg Rüpke]], ''Domi Militiae: Die religiöse Konstruktion des Krieges in Rom'' (Franz Steiner, 1990), pp. 76–80.</ref> ''Sacramentum'' also referred to a thing that was pledged as a sacred [[wikt:bond|bond]], and consequently forfeit if the oath were violated.<ref>D. Briquel "Sur les aspects militaires du dieu ombrien Fisus Sancius" in ''Revue de l' histoire des religions''{{full|date=November 2012}} i p. 150-151; J. A. C. Thomas ''A Textbook of Roman law'' Amsterdam 1976 p. 74 and 105.</ref> Both instances imply an underlying ''sacratio'', act of consecration.
The ''sacramentum'' differs from ''iusiurandum'', which is more common in legal application, as for instance swearing an oath in court. A ''sacramentum'' establishes a direct relation between the person swearing (or the thing pledged in the swearing of the oath) and the gods; the ''iusiurandum'' is an oath of good faith within the human community that is in accordance with ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#ius|ius]]'' as witnessed by the gods.<ref>[[Arnaldo Momigliano]], ''Quinto contributo alla storia degli studi classici e del mondo antico'' (Storia e letteratura, 1975), vol. 2, pp. 975–977; Luca Grillo, ''The Art of Caesar's Bellum Civile: Literature, Ideology, and Community'' (Cambridge University Press, 2012), p. 60.</ref>
''Sacramentum'' is the origin of the English word "[[sacrament]]", a transition in meaning pointed to by [[Apuleius]]'s use of the word to refer to [[mystery religions|religious initiation]].<ref>[[Apuleius]], ''[[The Golden Ass|Metamorphoses]]'' 11.15.5; Robert Schilling, "The Decline and Survival of Roman Religion," in ''Roman and European Mythologies'' (University of Chicago Press, 1992, from the French edition of 1981)</ref>
==Legal usage== In Roman law, a thing given as a pledge or bond was a ''sacramentum''. The ''sacramentum legis actio'' was a sum of money deposited in a legal procedure<ref>Varro ''De Lingua latina'' V 180; Festus s.v. ''sacramentum'' p. 466 L; 511 L; Paulus Festi Epitome p.467 L.</ref> to affirm that both parties to the litigation were acting in good faith.<ref>George Mousourakis, ''A Legal History of Rome'' (Routledge, 2007), p. 33.</ref> If correct law and procedures had been followed, it could be assumed that the outcome was ''iustum'', right or valid. The losing side had thus in effect committed [[perjury]], and forfeited his ''sacramentum'' as a form of ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#piaculum|piaculum]]'', an expiatory sacrifice; the winner got his deposit back. The forfeited ''sacramentum'' was normally allotted by the state to the funding of ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#sacra|sacra publica]]'', public religious rites.<ref>Mousourakis, ''A Legal History of Rome'', pp. 33, 206.</ref>
==Military oath== The ''sacramentum militare'' (also as ''militum'' or ''militiae'') was the oath taken by soldiers in pledging their loyalty to the [[Roman consul|consul]] in the [[Roman Republic|Republican era]] or later to the [[Roman emperor|emperor]]. The ''sacramentum'' as pertaining to both the law and the military indicates the religious basis for these institutions.
The text of the oath was recorded by [[Flavius Vegetius Renatus|Vegetius]]:<ref>Vegetius 2.5.</ref> :''Iurant autem milites omnia se strenue facturos quae praeceperit imperator, numquam deserturos militiam nec mortem recusaturos pro Romana republica''! :("But the soldiers swear that they shall faithfully execute all that the Emperor commands, that they shall never desert the service, and that they shall not seek to avoid death for the Roman republic!")
The ''sacramentum'' that renders the soldier ''sacer'' helps explain why he was subjected to harsher penalties, such as execution and corporal punishment, that were considered inappropriate for civilian citizens, at least under the Republic.<ref>See further discussion at ''[[fustuarium]]''</ref> In effect, he had put his life on deposit, a condition also of the fearsome ''sacramentum'' sworn by [[gladiator]]s.<ref>Gladiators swore to commit their bodies to the possibility of being "burned, bound, beaten, and slain by the sword"; [[Petronius]], ''Satyricon'' 117; Seneca, ''Epistulae'' 71.32.</ref> In the rare case of punishment by [[Decimation (Roman army)|decimation]], the surviving [[legionaries]] were often required to renew their oath, affirming the role of state ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#religio|religio]]'' as the foundation of Roman [[military discipline]].
By the 3rd century the ''sacramentum'' was administered annually, on January 3, as attested by the calendar of state ritual discovered at [[Dura-Europos]], the so-called ''[[Feriale Duranum]]'', which dates to the reign of [[Severus Alexander]] (222-235 CE).<ref>A.D. Nock, "The roman army and the Roman religious year", ''Harvard Theological Review'' '''45''' (1952:187-252).</ref> In the later empire, the oath of loyalty created conflict for Christians serving in the military, and produced a number of [[military saints|soldier-martyrs]].<ref>Carlin A. Barton, ''The Sorrows of the Ancient Romans: The Gladiator and the Monster'' (Princeton University Press, 1993), pp. 14–16, 35 (note 88), 42, 45–47.</ref> [[Tertullian]] condemned any Christian soldier's willingness to swear the ''sacramentum'', since [[baptism]] was the only [[sacrament]] a Christian should observe.<ref>Tertullian, ''De corona''{{full|date=November 2012}}, as noted by Paul Stephenson, ''Constantine, Roman Emperor, Christian Victor'', 2010:58.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

'''Scott Plous''' is an academic social psychologist, currently working as a Professor of Psychology at the Department of Psychology, [[Wesleyan University]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wesleyan.edu/templates/dept/psyc/skeleton_faculty.htt?function=f1&department=psyc&faculty=splous |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521152242/http://www.wesleyan.edu/templates/dept/psyc/skeleton_faculty.htt?function=f1&department=PSYC&faculty=splous |archivedate=2014-05-21 |df= }}</ref>
His areas of research include the psychology of prejudice and discrimination, judgment and decision making, international security and counter-terrorism, interactive web-based research, and the human use of animals and the environment. He is also the founder of the Social Psychology Network.<ref>[http://www.socialpsychology.org/plous.htm Socialpsychology.org]</ref><ref>[http://newsletter.blogs.wesleyan.edu/2009/05/19/700k-nsf-grant-will-transform-plous-website/ Newsletter.blog.wesleyan.edu]</ref>
Plous coined the term “action teaching” in 2000.<ref>Plous, S. (2000). Responding to overt displays of prejudice: A role-playing exercise. Teaching of Psychology, 27, 198-200. (For a free copy, visit www.understandingprejudice.org/pdf/roleplay.pdf)</ref> In this article he presented action teaching as the pedagogical counterpart to action research, a term coined by [[Kurt Lewin]] in the aftermath of World War II (Marrow, 1969). This experience of action teaching, he says, “leads not only to a better understanding of psychology but to a more just, compassionate and peaceful world.” <ref>Azar, B. (2008, December). Bringing lessons to life. Monitor on Psychology, 39, 56-58. (For a free copy, visit www.socialpsychology.org/pdf/action-teaching.pdf)</ref>
In 2001, he published a study that evaluated the reliability of [[Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee]]s (IACUCs), and found that animal testing standards in the United States are widely inconsistent across different research institutions.<ref>[http://www.socialpsychology.org/articles/scipress.htm Study Finds Inconsistency in Animal Research Reviews], Wesleyan University; July 27, 2001</ref>
Plous has published two books, and numerous journal articles, on social issues, animal rights, and psychology. He is best known as a founder of [[Social Psychology Network]], a suite of nonprofit web sites supported by the [[National Science Foundation]], created in 1996. Currently Plous also teaches social psychology online through [[Coursera|Coursera's]] MOOC<ref>https://www.coursera.org/course/socialpsychology/</ref>
==Publications==

New York: McGraw-Hill. {{ISBN|978-0-07-050477-6}} [Translated into Chinese, Korean, Norwegian, and Russian; hardbound edition concurrently published by Temple University Press.] *Plous, S. (Ed.). (2003). ''Understanding prejudice and discrimination.'' New York: McGraw-Hill. {{ISBN|978-0-07-255443-4}}

"Tips on creating and maintaining an educational web site". ''Teaching of Psychology'', 27, 63-70. *Plous, S. (1998). "Ten myths about affirmative action". ''[[Journal of Social Issues]]'', 52, 25-31. *Plous, S., & Herzog, H. A., Jr. (2001). "Reliability of protocol reviews for animal research". ''Science'', 293, 608-609. *Plous, S., & Herzog, H. A., Jr. (1999, June). "Should AWA coverage be broadened? Results from a survey of animal care and use committees". ''Lab Animal'', pp. 38–40. *Plous, S., & Neptune, D. (1997). "Racial and gender biases in magazine advertising: A content-analytic study". ''[[Psychology of Women Quarterly]]'', 21, 627-644. *Plous, S., & Williams, T. (1995). "Racial stereotypes from the days of American slavery: A continuing legacy". ''[[Journal of Applied Social Psychology]]'', 25, 795-817.

{{Infobox Halacha |image=[[Image:Schect.jpg|250px]] |caption=A 15th-century depiction of ''shechita'' and ''[[#Bedikah|bedikah]]''. |verse={{Bibleverse||Deuteronomy|12:21|JPR}}, {{Bibleverse||Deuteronomy|14:21|JPR}}, {{Bibleverse||Numbers|11:22|JPR}} |mishnah=[[Hullin]] |talmud=[[Hullin]] |talmudy= |rambam= Sefer Kodashim, Hilchot shechita |sa=[[Yoreh De'ah]] 1:27 |codes=[[Sefer ha-Chinuch]] mitzvah 451}} In Judaism, '''''shechita''''' (anglicized: {{IPAc-en|ʃ|ə|x|iː|ˈ|t|ɑː|}}; {{lang-he-n|{{linktext|שחיטה}}}}; {{IPA-he|ʃχiˈta|}}; also [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] ''shehitah, shechitah, shehita'') is slaughtering of certain mammals and birds for food according to ''[[kashrut]]'' ({{bibleverse||Deut.|12:21|HE}}, {{bibleverse||Deut.|14:21|HE}}, {{bibleverse||Num.|11:22|HE}}).
==Biblical source== The [[Torah]] ({{bibleverse||Deut.|12:21|HE||}}) states that sheep and cattle should be slaughtered "as I have instructed you" but nowhere in the [[Five books of Moses]] are any of the practices of ''shechita'' described.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The Essential Talmud|last=Steinsaltz|first=Adin|publisher=|year=June 17, 1976|isbn=|location=|pages=224-225}}</ref> Instead, they have been handed down in Judaism's traditional [[Oral Torah]], and codified in [[halakha]].
==Species== {{main|Kashrut#Permitted and forbidden animals}} The animal must be of a permitted species. For mammals, this is restricted to [[ruminants]] which have [[Cloven hoof|split hooves]].<ref>[[Shulchan Aruch]], [[Yoreh De'ah]] 79</ref> For birds, although biblically any species of bird not specifically excluded in {{Bibleverse||Deuteronomy|14:12–18}} would be permitted,<ref name = "Zivotofsky1"> {{cite web |url = http://www.kashrut.com/articles/turk_part1/ |title = Kashrut of Birds – The Biblical Story |first = Ari Z. |last = Zivotofsky |year = 2011 |work = Is Turkey Kosher? |publisher = Scharf Associates |accessdate =3 January 2012}} </ref> doubts as to the identity and scope of the species on the biblical list led to [[De-'oraita and de-rabbanan|rabbinical law]] permitting only birds with a tradition of being permissible.<ref name = "Zivotofsky3">{{cite web |url = http://www.kashrut.com/articles/turk_part3/ |title = Kashrut of Birds – The Need for a Mesorah |first = Ari Z. |last = Zivotofsky |year = 2011 |work = Is Turkey Kosher? |publisher = Scharf Associates |accessdate =3 January 2012 }} </ref> Fish do not require kosher slaughter to be considered kosher, but are subject to other laws found in {{Bibleverse||Leviticus|11:9–12}}which determine whether or not they are kosher.
== Shochtim == In the [[Talmud]]ic era (beginning in 200 CE with the [[Jerusalem Talmud]] and 300 CE with the [[Babylonian Talmud]] and extending through the medieval ages), rabbis started to debate and define kosher laws. As the laws increased in number and complexity, following [[ritual slaughter]] laws became difficult for Jews who were not trained in those laws. This resulted in the need for a ''shochet'' (someone who has studied shechita extensively) to perform the slaughtering in the communities.<ref name=":1" />
The ''shochtim'' (plural of ''shochet'') study which slaughtered animals are kosher, what disqualifies them from being kosher, and how to prepare animals according to the laws of shechita. Subjects of study include the preparation of slaughtering tools, ways to interpret which foods follow the laws of shechita, and types of ''[[Terefah|terefot]]'' (unfit kosher animals).<ref name=":1" />
Shochtim studied under rabbis to learn the laws of shechita. Rabbis acted as the academics who, among themselves, debated how to apply laws from the Torah to the preparation of animals. Rabbis also conducted experiments to determine under which terefot animals were no-longer kosher. Shochtim studied under these rabbis, as rabbis were the officials who first interpret, debate, and determine the laws of shechita.<ref name=":1" />
Shochtim are essential to every Jewish community, so they earn elevated social status. In medieval ages, the shochtim were treated as second in social status, just underneath rabbis. Shochtim were respected for committing their time to studying and for their importance to their communities.<ref name=":1" />
==Procedure== [[File:Shalom Koboshvili. Slaughtering poultry according to religious rules. Oil on canvas. 70.5×101 cm. 1940.jpg|thumb|Slaughtering poultry according to religious rules, [[Shalom Koboshvili]], 1940]]
The procedure, which must be performed by a ''shochet'' ({{lang|he|[[:wikt:שוחט|שוחט]]}}), involves severing the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]], [[esophagus]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.21?lang=bi|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 21 |last=|first=|date=|website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> and, crucially, the large blood vessels of the neck, in a swift action using a [[#The knife|special knife]] with an extremely sharp blade.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.6?lang=bi|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 6 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> The procedure may be performed with the animal either lying on its back ({{lang|he|שחיטה מוונחת}}, ''shechita munachat'') or standing ({{lang|he|שחיטה מעומדת}}, ''shechita me'umedet'').<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Mishneh_Torah,_Ritual_Slaughter.2.7?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Mishneh Torah, Ritual Slaughter 2:7 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> In the case of fowl (with the exception of large fowl like Turkey) the bird is held in the non-dominant hand in such a way that the head is pulled back and the neck exposed, while the cut made with the dominant hand.<ref> Sefer Beit David 24:4 </ref>
The procedure is done with the intention of causing a rapid drop in blood pressure in the brain and loss of consciousness, to render the animal insensitive to pain and to [[Exsanguination|exsanguinate]] in a prompt and precise action.<ref>[http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/222240/jewish/What-is-Shechita.htm What is Shechita?] chabad.org</ref><ref>[https://www.shechitauk.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Physiological_insights_into_Shechita__S.D.Rosen__Veterinary_Record_2004_01.pdf?x55307 S. D. Rosen. Physiological Insights into Shechita.'' The Veterinary Record'' June 12, 2004'']</ref> However, severing the carotid arteries and jugular veins does not cut blood flow to the brain of a bovine, because the brain is supplied with blood also by vertebral arteries. <ref>Zdun, M., Frąckowiak, H., Kiełtyka-Kurc, A., Kowalczyk, K., Nabzdyk, M. and Timm, A. (2013), The Arteries of Brain Base in Species of Bovini Tribe. Anat. Rec., 296: 1677–1682. doi:10.1002/ar.22784</ref>
If one did not sever the entirety of both the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]] and [[esophagus]], then an animal may still be considered kosher as long as one severed the majority of the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]] and [[esophagus]] (windpipe and food pipe) of a mammal, or the majority of either one of these in the case of birds.<ref name=":0" /> The cut must be incised with a back and forth motion without violating one of the five major prohibited techniques<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.23?lang=bi|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 23 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> (see [[#Forbidden techniques|below]]), or various other detailed rules.
==Forbidden techniques== *'''Shehiyah''' ({{Hebrew|שהייה}}; delay or pausing) - Pausing during the incision and then starting to cut again makes the animal's flesh unkosher.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.23.2?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 23:2 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> The knife must be moved across the neck in an uninterrupted motion until the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]] and [[esophagus]] are sufficiently severed to avoid this.<ref name=":0" /> There is some disagreement among legal sources as to the exact length of time needed to constitute shehiyah, but today the normative practice is to disqualify a kosher cut as a result of any length of pausing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.23.2?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 23:2 |last=|first=|date=|website= [[Sefaria]]|others=Rama's commentary on Shulchan Aruch 23-2 requires strict adherence to disqualifying any pause.|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> *'''Derasah''' ({{Hebrew|דרסה}}; pressing/chopping) - The knife must be drawn across the throat by a back and forth movement, not by chopping, hacking, or pressing without moving the knife back and forth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.24.1?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 24:1 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> There are those<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=20027&st=&pgnum=173|title=שו"ת תשובות והנהגות ח"ד - שטרנבוך, משה (page 173 of 568)|website=www.hebrewbooks.org|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> who assert that it is forbidden to have the animal in an upright position during shechita due to the prohibition of derasah. They maintain that the animal must be on its back or lying on its side, and some also allow for the animal to be suspended upside down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://forward.com/news/12666/shackle-and-hoist-kosher-slaughter-comes-under-01274/|title=Widespread Slaughter Method Scrutinized for Alleged Cruelty|work=The Forward|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> However, the Rambam explicitly permits upright slaughter,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Mishneh_Torah,_Ritual_Slaughter.2.7?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Mishneh Torah, Ritual Slaughter 2:7 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> and the Orthodox Union as well as all other major kosher certifiers in the United States accept upright slaughter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.star-k.org/articles/kashrus-kurrents/548/a-cut-above-shechita-in-the-crosshairs-again/|title=A Cut Above: Shechita in the Crosshairs, Again {{!}} STAR-K Kosher Certification|last=|first=|date=|website=www.star-k.org|at=A standing Matter|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> *'''Haladah''' ({{Hebrew|חלדה}}; covering, digging, or burying) - The knife must be drawn over the throat so that the back of the knife is at all times visible while shechita is being performed. It must not be stabbed into the neck or buried by fur, hide, feathers, the wound itself, or a foreign object (such as a scarf) which may cover the knife.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.24.7?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 24:7 |website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> *'''Hagramah''' ({{Hebrew|הגרמה}}; cutting in the wrong location) - Hagramah refers to the location on the neck on which a kosher cut may be performed; cutting outside this location will in most cases disqualify a kosher cut.<ref name="24:12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.24.12?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 24:12|website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> According to today's normative Orthodox practice, any cutting outside this area will in all cases disqualify a kosher cut.<ref name="24:12"/> The limits within which the knife may be applied are from the large ring in the windpipe to the top of the upper lobe of the lung when it is inflated, and corresponding to the length of the pharynx. Slaughtering above or below these limits renders the meat unkosher. *'''Iqqur''' ({{Hebrew|עיקור}}; tearing) - If either the esophagus or the trachea is torn during the shechita incision, the carcass is rendered unkosher. Iqqur can occur if one tears out the esophagus or trachea while handling an animal's neck or if the esophagus or trachea is torn by a knife with imperfection/s on the blade, such as nicks or serration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh,_Yoreh_De'ah.24.15?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en|title=Shulchan Arukh, Yoreh De'ah 24:15|website= [[Sefaria]]|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grandin.com/ritual/rules.shechita.proper.cut.html |title=The rules of Shechita for performing a proper cut during kosher slaughter (Rabbi Chanoch Kesselman, Temple Grandin, meat scientist) |publisher=Grandin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/13531-shehitah |title=Article: ''Shehitah'' Jewish Encyclopedia 1906 |publisher=Jewishencyclopedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> In order to avoid tearing, the kosher slaughter knife is expertly maintained and regularly checked with the shochet's fingernail to ensure that no nicks are present.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thekosheromnivoresquest.com/blog/deconstructing-kosher-slaughter-part-2-the-basics|title=Deconstructing Kosher Slaughter Part 2: The Basics|website=The Kosher Omnivore's Quest|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>
Breaching any of these five rules renders the animal ''[[nevelah]]''; the animal is regarded in Jewish law as if it were [[carrion]].
[[Temple Grandin]] has observed that "if the rules (of the five forbidden techniques) are disobeyed, the animal will struggle. If these rules are obeyed, the animal has little reaction."<ref>{{Cite web|title = The rules of Shechita for performing a proper cut during kosher slaughter|url = http://www.grandin.com/ritual/rules.shechita.proper.cut.html|website = www.grandin.com|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
==The knife== [[File:Shechita.JPG|thumb|Shechita slaughter of a [[chicken]]]]
The knife used for shechita is called a ''sakin'' ({{Hebrew|סכין}}), or alternatively a ''hallaf'' ({{Hebrew|חלף}}) by [[Ashkenazi Jews]]. By biblical law the knife may be made from anything not attached directly or indirectly to the ground and capable of being sharpened and polished to the necessary level of sharpness and smoothness required for shechita. The [[Minhag]] now is to use a metal knife.
The knife must be at least slightly longer than the neck width but preferably at least twice as long as the animal's neck is wide, but not so long that the weight of the knife is deemed excessive. If the knife is too large, it is assumed to cause ''Derasah'', excessive pressing. Kosher knife makers sell knives of differing sizes depending on the animal. Shorter blades may technically be used depending on the number of strokes employed to slaughter the animal, but the normative practice today is that shorter blades are not used. The knife must not have a point. It is feared a point may slip into the wound during slaughter and cause ''Haladah'', covering, of the blade. The blade may also not be serrated, as serrations cause ''Iqqur,'' tearing.
The blade may not have imperfections in it. All blades are assumed by Jewish law to be imperfect, so the knife must be checked before each session. In the past the knife was checked through a variety of means. Today the common practice is for the shochet to run his fingernail up and down both sides of the blade and on the cutting edge to determine if he can feel any imperfections. He then uses a number of increasingly fine abrasive stones to sharpen and polish the blade until it is perfectly sharp and smooth. After the slaughter, the shochet must check the knife again in the same way to be certain the first inspection was properly done, and to ensure the blade was not damaged during shechita. If the blade is found to be damaged, the meat may not be eaten by Jews. If the blade falls or is lost before the second check is done, the first inspection is relied on and the meat is permitted.
In previous centuries, the hallaf was made of forged steel, which was not reflective and was difficult to make both smooth and sharp. [[Shneur Zalman of Liadi]], fearing that [[Sabbateans]] were scratching the knives in a way not detectable by normal people, introduced the [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] ''hallaf''{{nnbsp}} ({{transl|yi|hasidishe hallaf}}). It differs from the previously-used knife design because it is made of molten steel and polished to a mirror gloss in which scratches could be seen as well as felt. The new knife was controversial and one of the reasons for the 1772 [[excommunication]] of the Hasidim.<ref>{{cite book|last=Vertheim|first=Aharon|title=Law and Custom in Hasidism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_n-Hb634XUIC&pg=PA302|year=1992|publisher=KTAV Publishing House, Inc.|isbn=978-0-88125-401-3|pages=302–}}</ref>
==Other rules== The animal may not be [[Stunning|stunned]] prior to the procedure, as is common practice in non-kosher modern [[animal slaughter]] since the early twentieth century.
It is forbidden to [[Prohibition against slaughtering an animal and its offspring on the same day|slaughter an animal and its young on the same day]].<ref> {{bibleverse||Leviticus|22:28|HE||}}</ref> An animal's "young" is defined as either its own offspring, or another animal that follows it around, even if of another species.
The animal's blood may not be collected in a bowl, a pit, or a body of water, as these resemble ancient forms of [[idolatry|idol worship]].
If the shochet accidentally slaughters with a knife dedicated to idol worship, he must remove an amount of meat equivalent to the value of the knife and destroy it. If he slaughtered with such a knife on purpose, the animal is forbidden as not kosher.
==Post-procedure requirements==
===Bedikah=== The carcass must be checked to see if the animal had any of a specific list of internal injuries that would have rendered the animal a [[terefah|treifah]] before the slaughter. These injuries were established by the Talmudic Rabbis as being likely to cause the animal to die within 12 months time. Today all mammals are inspected for lung [[Adhesion (medicine)|adhesion]]s ({{transl|he|bedikat ha-reah}} "examination of the lung") and other disqualifying signs of the lungs, and most kosher birds will have their intestines inspected for infections. Further inspection of other parts of the body may be performed depending on the stringency applied and also depending on whether any signs of sickness were detected before slaughter or during the processing of the animal.
====Glatt==== ''Glatt'' ({{lang-yi|גלאַט}}) and ''halak'' ({{lang-he|חלק}}) both mean "smooth". In the context of kosher meat, they refer to the "smoothness" (lack of blemish) in the internal organs of the animal. In the case of an [[Adhesion (medicine)|adhesion]] on a cow’s lungs specifically, there is debate between [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazic]] customs and [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardic]] customs. While there are certain areas of the lung where an adhesion is allowed, the debate revolves around adhesions which do not occur in these areas.
Ashkenazic Jews rule that if the adhesion can be removed (there are various methods of removing the adhesion, and not all of them are acceptable even according to the Ashkenazic custom) and the lungs are still airtight (a process that is tested by filling the lungs with air and then submerging them in water and looking for escaping air), then the animal is still kosher but not ''glatt''. If, in addition, there were two or fewer adhesions, and they were small and easily removable, then these adhesions are considered a lesser type of adhesion, and the animal is considered ''glatt''.<ref>https://www.yeshiva.co/ask/?id=6507</ref> Ashkenazi custom permits eating non-''glatt kosher'' meat, but it is often considered praiseworthy to only eat ''glatt'' kosher meat.<ref name="yhb">http://en.yhb.org.il/2012/02/17/the-difference-between-glatt-and-kosher-meat/</ref>
Sephardic Jews rule that if there is any sort of adhesion on the forbidden areas of the lungs, then the animal is not kosher. This standard is commonly known as ''halak [[Beit Yosef (book)|Beit Yosef]]''. It is the strictest in terms of which adhesions are allowed.
The [[Moses Isserles|Rema]] (an Ashkenazi authority) had an additional stringency, of checking adhesions on additional parts of the lung which Sephardi practice does not require. Some Ashkenazi Jews keep this stringency.<ref name="yhb"/>
===Nikkur {{anchor|Porging}}=== ''Porging''{{refn|group=note|The English word ''porge'' is from [[Judeo-Spanish]] ''porgar'' (from Spanish {{lang|es|purgar}} "to purge").<ref>{{Merriam-Webster|porge}}</ref> The Hebrew is ''nikkur'' (''niqqur'') and the Yiddish is ''treibering''. This is done by a ''menaḳḳer'' (Yiddish).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/12288-porging |title=Porging |publisher=Jewish Encyclopedia |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>}} refers to the halakhic requirement to remove the carcass's [[veins]], ''[[chelev]]'' ([[caul fat]] and [[suet]])<ref>[[Mishneh Torah]] ''Kedushah'', ''Forbidden Foods'' 8:1</ref> and [[sinews]].<ref>[[Mishneh Torah]] ''Kedushah'', ''Forbidden Foods'' 6:1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/12288-porging |title=Porging |work=Jewish Encyclopedia 1905 |publisher=Jewishencyclopedia.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> The [[Torah]] prohibits the eating of certain fats, so they must be removed from the animal. These fats are typically known as ''chelev''. There is also a biblical prohibition against eating the [[sciatic nerve]] (''[[gid hanasheh]]''), so that, too, is removed.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title = PORGING |encyclopedia = Jewish Encyclopedia |volume = 10 |pages = 132 |publisher = [[Funk & Wagnalls]] |location = New York |date = 19 June 1901 |lccn = 16014703 |last = Eisenstein |first = Judah David |url = http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=453&letter=P |accessdate =3 January 2012 }}</ref>
The removal of the ''chelev'' and the ''gid hanasheh'', called ''[[nikkur]]'', is considered complicated and tedious, and hence labor-intensive, and even more specialized training is necessary to perform the act properly. While the small amounts of ''chelev'' in the front half of the animal are relatively easy to remove, the back half of the animal is far more complicated, and it is where the sciatic nerve is located.
In countries such as the United States, where there exists a large nonkosher meat market, the [[Cut of beef#Hindquarter cuts|hindquarters]] of the animal (where many of these forbidden meats are located) is often sold to non-Jews, rather than trouble with the process. This tradition goes back for centuries<ref>[http://www.kashrut.com/articles/nikkur/ What's the Truth about Nikkur Achoraim?] kashrut.com, 2007</ref> where local Muslims accept meat slaughtered by Jews as consumable; however, the custom was not universal throughout the [[Muslim world]], and some Muslims (particularly on the [[Indian subcontinent]]) did not accept these hindquarters as [[halal]]. In [[Israel]], on the other hand, specially trained men are hired to prepare the hindquarters for sale as kosher.
===Blood removal=== Because of the biblical prohibition of eating blood ({{bibleverse||Gen|9:4|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Lev|17:10–14|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Deut|12:23–24|KJV}}), all blood must be promptly removed from the carcass. All large arteries and veins are removed, as well as any bruised meat or coagulated blood. Then the meat is ''kasher''ed, a process of soaking and salting the meat to draw out all the blood. If this procedure is not performed promptly, the blood is considered to have “set” in the meat, and the meat is no longer salvageable to eat except when prepared through broiling with appropriate drainage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wikihow.com/Kosher-Meat |title=Wikihow. How to Kasher Meat |publisher=Wikihow.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>
===Giving of the Gifts=== {{main|foreleg, cheeks and maw}} A [[Biblical commandment]] states a shochet must give the [[foreleg, cheeks and maw]] to a [[Kohen]] even though he does not own the meat. Thus, it is desirable that the shochet refuse to perform the shechita unless the animal's owner expresses his agreement to give the gifts. [[Beth din|Betei din]] (Rabbinical courts) have the authority to [[Herem (censure)|excommunicate]] a shochet who refuses to perform this commandment.
The [[Rishonim]] point out the Shochet cannot claim that, since the animal does not belong to him, he cannot give the gifts without the owner's consent. On the contrary, since the average shochet is reputed to be well versed and knowledgeable in the laws of Shechitah ("Dinnei Shechita"), Beith Din relies on him to withhold his shechita so long as the owner refuses to give the gifts:
{{quote|The obligation of giving the gifts lay upon the Shochet to separate the parts due to the Kohanim. Apparently, the reasoning is that since the average Shochet is a "[[Talmid Chacham|Friend]]", since he completed the prerequisite of understanding the (complex) laws of Shechita and Bedikah. It is assumed that he -as well- is knowledgeable in the details of the laws of giving the gifts, and will not put the [[Mitzvah]] aside. This, however, is not the case with the animal's owner, since the average owner is an [[Am ha'aretz|Am ha-aretz]] not wholly knowledgeable in the laws of the gifts -and procrastinates in completing the Mitzvah''|Shulchan Gavoah to Yoreh Deah 61:61}}
==Covering Of The Blood==
it is a positive commandment incumbent upon the shochet to cover the blood of חיות (non-domesticated animals) and עופות (birds) but not בהמות (domesticated animals).<ref>[https://www.sefaria.org/Mishneh_Torah%2C_Ritual_Slaughter.14?lang=he Mishnah Torah, laws of kosher slaughter 14:1]</ref> The shochet is required to place dirt on the ground before the slaughter and then to perform the cut over that dirt in order to drop some of the blood on to the prepared dirt. When the shechita is complete, the shochet grabs a handful of dirt, says a blessing and then covers the blood. The meat is still Kosher if the blood does not get covered; the covering of the blood is a separate mitzvah which does not affect the kosher status of the meat.
==Animal welfare controversies== {{see also|Legal aspects of ritual slaughter}}
===General description of controversy=== The practices of handling, restraining, and unstunned slaughter have been criticized by, among others, animal welfare organizations such as [[Compassion in World Farming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ciwf.org.uk/news/compassion_news/plea_on_unstunned_halal_and_kosher_meat.aspx |title=Compassion in World Farming: Unstunned Hallal and Kosher Meat (with link to collected reports) |publisher=Ciwf.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> The UK [[Farm Animal Welfare Council]] said that the method by which Kosher and [[Halal]] meat is produced causes "significant pain and distress" to animals and should be banned.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/end-cruel-religious-slaughter-say-scientists-1712241.html | location=London |work=The Independent | first=Martin | last=Hickman | date=22 June 2009 | title=End 'cruel' religious slaughter, say scientists}}</ref> According to FAWC it can take up to two minutes after the incision for cattle to become insensible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fawc.org.uk/reports/pb8347.pdf |title=Farm Animal Welfare Council: Report on the Welfare of Farmed Animals at Slaughter or Killing Part 1: Red Meat Animals |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531191226/http://www.fawc.org.uk/reports/pb8347.pdf |archivedate=31 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Compassion in World Farming]] also supported the recommendation saying "We believe that the law must be changed to require all animals to be stunned before slaughter."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/talking_point/2977678.stm |title=BBC: Should Halal and Kosher meat be banned? |publisher=BBC News |date=16 June 2003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2977086.stm |title=BBC: Halal and Kosher slaughter 'must end' |publisher=BBC News |date=10 June 2003 }}</ref> The UK government opted not to follow FAWC's recommendations after pressure from religious leaders.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kirby |first=Terry |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/government-backs-down-on-religious-slaughter-ban-558596.html |title=Government backs down on religious slaughter ban''The Independent'' |work=The Independent |date=2 April 2004 |location=London}}</ref> The [[Federation of Veterinarians of Europe]] has issued a position paper on slaughter without prior stunning, calling it "unacceptable."<ref>[{{cite web|url=http://www.fve.org/news/position_papers/animal_welfare/fve_02_104_slaughter_prior_stunning.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Federation of Veterinarians of Europe|title=Slaughter of Animals Without Prior Stunning}}</ref>
[[Nick Cohen]], writing for the ''[[New Statesman]]'', discusses research papers collected by Compassion in World Farming which indicate that the animal suffers pain during the process.<ref name = "TNS">{{cite journal | last1 = Cohen | first1 = Nick | date = 5 July 2004 | title = God's own chosen meat | journal = New Statesman | volume = 133 | issue = 4695 | pages = 22–23 | issn = 1364-7431 | accessdate =3 January 2012 | url = http://www.newstatesman.com/200407050016 | quote = Possible reasons for the suffering are laid out in various research papers that Compassion in World Farming has collected. After the throat is cut, large clots can form at the severed ends of the carotid arteries, leading to occlusion of the wound (or "ballooning" as it is known in the slaughtering trade). Occlusions slow blood loss from the carotids and delay the decline in blood pressure that prevents the suffering brain from blacking out. In one group of calves, 62.5 per cent suffered from ballooning. Even if the slaughterman is a master of his craft and the cut to the neck is clean, blood is carried to the brain by vertebral arteries, and it keeps cattle conscious of their pain. }}</ref> In 2009, Craig Johnson and colleagues showed that calves that have not been stunned feel pain from the cut in their necks,<ref name=GibsonEtAl2009>{{cite journal|author1=TJ Gibson|author2=CB Johnson|author3=JC Murrell|author4=CM Hulls|author5=SL Mitchinson|author6=KJ Stafford|author7=AC Johnstone|author8=DJ Mellor|title=Electroencephalographic responses of halothane-anaesthetised calves to slaughter by ventral-neck incision without prior stunning|journal=New Zealand Veterinary Journal|date=13 Feb 2009|volume=57|issue=2|pages=77–83|doi=10.1080/00480169.2009.36882}}</ref> and they may take at least 10–30 seconds to lose consciousness.<ref name=Coghlan2009>{{cite news|author1=Andy Coghlan|title=Animals feel the pain of religious slaughter|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17972-animals-feel-the-pain-of-religious-slaughter.html|accessdate=21 January 2015|agency=New Scientist|date=13 Oct 2009}}</ref> This has led to prohibitions against unstunned slaughter in some countries.
Generally these arguments are rejected by the Jewish community, who say that the method is humane and that criticism is at least partially motivated by [[antisemitism]]. A [[Knesset]] committee announced (January, 2012) that it would call on European parliaments and the [[European Union]] to put a stop to attempts to outlaw kosher slaughter. "The pretext [for this legislation] is preventing cruelty to animals or animal rights – but there is sometimes an element of anti-Semitism and there is a hidden message that Jews are cruel to animals," said Committee Chair MK [[Danny Danon]] ([[Likud]]).<ref>{{cite web|last=Harman |first=Danna |url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/israeli-knesset-committee-seeks-end-to-european-bans-on-kosher-slaughter-1.406578 |title=Israeli Knesset committee seeks end to European bans on kosher slaughter ''Ha'aretz'' Knesset Committee on Immigration, Absorption and Diaspora Affairs chair says attempts to outlaw 'Shechita' contain 'anti-Semitic' elements. ''Ha'aretz'' Johnathan Lis January 10, 2012 |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2012-01-10 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>
[[Research|Studies]] and [[experiment]]s cited on the Jewish internet site [[Chabad.org]] include one conducted in 1994 by Dr. [[Temple Grandin]] - an [[Associate Professor]] of [[Animal Science]] at [[Colorado]] and a study completed in 1992 by Dr. Flemming Bager, Head of the [[Danish Veterinary Laboratory]], which showed that when the animals were slaughtered in a comfortable position they appeared to give no resistance and none of the animals attempted to pull away their head. The studies concluded that the animals had no pain and were not even aware that their throats were cut.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is Shechita Humane?|url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/222248/jewish/Is-Shechita-Humane.htm|work=Dr. Temple Grandin, Dr. Flemming Bager -|publisher=Chabad.org|accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref>
[[Temple Grandin]] – a leading designer of animal handling systems – gives various research times for loss of consciousness via kosher and [[halal]] ritual slaughter and elaborates on what parts of the process she finds may or may not be cause for concern.<ref name = "TG1">{{cite web |url = http://www.grandin.com/ritual/welfare.diffs.sheep.cattle.html |title = Welfare During Slaughter without stunning (Kosher or Halal) differences between Sheep and Cattle |first = Temple |last = Grandin |authorlink = Temple Grandin |date=August 2011 |accessdate =3 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/articles/137318/maximizing-animal-welfare-in-kosher-slaughter/ |title=Temple Grandin ''Maximising Animal Welfare in Kosher Slaughter |publisher=Forward.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Grandin observes that the way animals are handled and restrained prior to slaughter likely has a greater impact on their welfare than whether or not they are stunned. For this reason, "under the leadership of Grandin, research into animal welfare during slaughter has shifted away from examination of different techniques of stunning to a focus on auditing the performance of actual slaughter plants operating under commercial conditions."<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Rushen |editor1-first=Jeffrey |editor2-last=de Passile |editor2-first=Anne Marie |editor3-last=von Keyserlingk |editor3-first=Marina A.G. |display-editors = 3 |editor4-last=Weary |editor4-first=Daniel M. |year=2008 |title=The Welfare of Cattle |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OEp52JU9IEwC&printsec=frontcover&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JVYZU8-9GYnmoAT9-oGYCw&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=140 |location=Dordrecht, The Netherlands |publisher=Springer |isbn=9781402065583 }}</ref>
===Efforts to improve conditions in shechita slaughterhouses=== Temple Grandin is opposed to shackling and hoisting as a method of handling animals and wrote, on visiting a shechita slaughterhouse, "I will never forget having nightmares after visiting the now defunct [[Spencer Foods]] plant in [[Spencer, Iowa]], fifteen years ago. Employees wearing football helmets attached a nose tong to the nose of a writhing beast suspended by a chain wrapped around one back leg. Each terrified animal was forced with an [[cattle prod|electric prod]] to run into a small stall which had a slick floor on a forty-five degree angle. This caused the animal to slip and fall so that workers could attach the chain to its rear leg [in order to raise it into the air]. As I watched this nightmare, I thought, 'This should not be happening in a civilized society.' In my diary I wrote, 'If hell exists, I am in it.' I vowed that I would replace the plant from hell with a kinder and gentler system."<ref>Temple Grandin ''Thinking in Pictures. My Life with Autism''</ref>
Efforts are made to improve the techniques used in slaughterhouses. Temple Grandin has worked closely with Jewish slaughterers to design handling systems for cattle, and has said: "When the cut is done correctly, the animal appears not to feel it. From an animal welfare standpoint, the major concern during ritual slaughter are the stressful and cruel methods of restraint (holding) that are used in some plants."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grandin.com/ritual/rec.ritual.slaughter.html |title=Recommended Ritual Slaughter Practices |publisher=Grandin.com }}</ref> When shackling and hoisting is used, it is recommended <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Handbook_of_Meat_and_Meat_Processing_Sec.html?id=1ZRCMRXbbwoC&redir_esc=y |title=Handbook of Meat and Meat Processing, Second Edition. Y. H. Hui (editor) |publisher=Books.google.se |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> that cattle not be hoisted clear of the floor until they have had time to bleed out.
===Agriprocessors controversy=== The prohibition of stunning and the treatment of the slaughtered animal expressed in shechita law limit the extent to which Jewish slaughterhouses can industrialize their procedures. The most industrialized attempt at a kosher [[slaughterhouse]], [[Agriprocessors]] of [[Postville]], [[Iowa]], became the center of controversy in 2004, after [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] released a gruesome undercover video of cattle struggling to their feet with their tracheas and esophagi ripped out after shechita. Some of the cattle actually got up and stood for a minute or so after being dumped from the rotating pen.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/30/national/30cnd-kosh.html?_r=0 The New York Times ''Videotapes Show Grisly Scenes at Kosher Slaughterhouse'' By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. November 30, 2004]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goveg.com/feat/agriprocessors |title=PETA Reveals Extreme Cruelty at Kosher Slaughterhouses | PETA.org |publisher=Goveg.com }}</ref><ref>Aaron Gross: [http://www.jewishveg.com/media11.html When Kosher Isn't Kosher]. [[Tikkun Magazine]], March/April 2005, Vol. 20, No. 2.</ref> Dr. [[Temple Grandin]], told [[Mason City, Iowa|Mason City]], [[Iowa]]'s ''[[Globe Gazette]]'', "I thought it was the most disgusting thing I'd ever seen. I couldn't believe it. I've been in at least 30 other kosher slaughter plants, and I had never ever seen that kind of procedure done before. … I've seen kosher slaughter really done right, so the problem here is not kosher slaughter. The problem here is a plant that is doing everything wrong they can do wrong."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peta.org/features/agriprocessors.aspx |title=PETA Reveals Extreme Cruelty at Kosher Slaughterhouses |publisher=Peta.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> While Agriprocessors has been criticized by both secular and Jewish organizations for both its [[human rights|human]] and [[animal rights]] violations, the [[Jewish Orthodox Union]] (OU) made note to point out that the [[kashrut]] of a product is not contingent upon "the conditions in which it is produced. {{citation needed|date=May 2013}} The OU's condonation of Agriprocessors as a possibly inhumane, yet appropriately [[Shechita#Glatt|glatt kosher]] company has led to discussion as to whether or not industrialized agriculture has undermined the place of [[halakha]] (Jewish law) in shechita as well as whether or not halakha has any place at all in Jewish ritual slaughter.<ref>{{cite book|last=Fishkoff|first= Sue|title= Kosher Nation|location= New York|publisher= Schocken|year= 2010}}</ref>
[[Jonathan Safran Foer]], a [[Jewish vegetarianism|Jewish vegetarian]], narrated the short documentary film ''If This Is Kosher...'', which records what he considers abuses within the kosher meat industry.<ref>{{cite web|last=Foer|first=Jonathan Safran|title=If This Is Kosher…|url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-7330038074290819722}}</ref> Forums surrounding the ethical treatment of workers and animals in kosher slaughterhouses have inspired a revival of the small-scale, kosher-certified farms and slaughterhouses, which are gradually appearing throughout the United States.<ref>{{cite web|last=Romanoff |first=Zan |url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/food/article/kosher_farm_to_table |title=Kosher – Farm to table | Food |publisher=Jewish Journal |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} The '''Simla Accord''', or the '''Convention Between Great Britain, China, and Tibet, [in] Simla''',<ref name="Conven1914">[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties16.html "Convention Between Great Britain, China, and Tibet, Simla (1914)"], [[Tibet Justice Center]]. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref> was a [[treaty]] concerning the status of [[Tibet]] negotiated by representatives of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]], [[Tibet (1912–1951)|Tibet]] and the [[United Kingdom]] in [[Shimla|Simla]] in 1913 and 1914.
The Accord provided that Tibet would be divided into "Outer Tibet" and "Inner Tibet". Outer Tibet, which roughly corresponded to [[Ü-Tsang]] and western [[Kham]], would "remain in the hands of the Tibetan Government at Lhasa under Chinese [[suzerainty]]", but China would not interfere in its administration. "Inner Tibet", roughly, equivalent to [[Amdo]] and eastern Kham, would be under the jurisdiction of the Chinese government. The Accord with its annexes also defines the boundary between Tibet and [[China proper]] and between Tibet and British India (the latter became known as the [[McMahon Line]]).<ref name="Conven1914"/><ref name=Sinha-1974-12>Sinha (Calcutta 1974), p. 12 (pdf p. 8)</ref><ref name=Sinha group=lower-alpha>The map was finalised on 24/25 March 1914 by the British and Tibetan plenipotentiaries. Indian sources currently claim that, on being informed of the line, the Chinese plenipotentiary did not express any disagreement.(Sinha, (Calcutta 1974), p. 12 (pdf p. 8)) {{quote|The two maps (27 April 1914 and 3 July 1914) illustrating the boundaries bear the full signature of the Tibetan Plenipotentiary; the first bears the full signature of the Chinese Plenipotentiary also; the second bears the full signatures along with seals of both Tibetan and British Plenipotentiaries. (V. Photographic reproductions of the two maps in ''Atlas of the North Frontier of India'', New Delhi: Ministry of External Affairs 1960)|Sinha (21 February 1966), p. 37}}
(Goldstein, M.C., ''A History of Modern Tibet, 1913–1951: The Demise of the Lamaist State'', 1989, p. 80. Quotes India Office records IOR/L/PS/10/344).
{{quote|The Indian Government opened bilateral negotiations with the Tibetans in Deli in February–March 1914 (the conferees having retreated from the Simla winter) with the object of securing Tibetan agreement to the proposed alignment. |Gupta, Karunakar, ''The McMahon Line 1911–45: The British Legacy''}} </ref>
China rejected the Accord and their [[plenipotentiary]], Ivan Chen, withdrew on 3 July 1914. The British and Tibetan plenipotentiaries then attached a note denying China any privileges under the Accord and sealed it as a bilateral agreement the same day.{{sfn|Goldstein|1991|p=837}}<ref group=lower-alpha>This Accord was initialled and sealed by the British plenipotentiary, A. Henry McMahon, and sealed by the Tibetan plenipotentiary Lochen Shatra but not the Chinese plenipotentiary, Ivan Chen, as he had withdrawn from the Convention before the Accord was initialled and sealed.([http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties16.html "Convention Between Great Britain, China, and Tibet, Simla (1914)"], [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009).</ref><ref name=Sinha-1974-5-12>Sinha (Calcutta 1974), pp. 5,12 (pdf pp. 1,8)</ref> The British records show that there are conditions for the Tibetan government to accept the new border in 1914, the condition was that China must accept the Simla Convention, since the British was not able to get an acceptance from China, Tibetans considered the [[McMahon Line]] invalid.<ref name="Shakya1999"/>
McMahon's work was initially rejected by the British government as incompatible with the 1907 [[Anglo-Russian Convention]]. This convention was renounced in 1921. The British began using the McMahon Line on [[Survey of India]] maps in 1937, and the Simla Accord was published officially in 1938.<ref group=lower-alpha>{{quote|The Simla Convention and its appended Indo-Tibetan agreement did not appear in Aitchison's Treaties (the official GOI record), including the final 1929 edition, since the unratified Simla Convention was not a valid international treaty and the Indo-Tibetan agreement was secret. The 1929 edition was withdrawn by a British Indian official, Olaf Caroe, in 1938, and a new edition was issued that included the Simla Convention and the McMahon-Shartra notes (but not the Anglo-Tibetan agreement or the McMahon Line map)|Smith, Warren, Tibetan Nation, p201, n163}}</ref>
==Background== Early British efforts to create a boundary for north-east India were triggered by their discovery in the mid-19th century that [[Tawang]], an important trading town, was Tibetan territory.<ref name="Calvin">Calvin, James Barnard, [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/1984/CJB.htm "The China-India Border War"], Marine Corps Command and Staff College, April 1984</ref> Britain had concluded treaties with [[Qing]] China concerning Tibet's boundaries with [[Burma]]<ref name="Conven1886">[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties8.html Convention Relating to Burmah and Tibet (1886)], [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref> and [[Sikkim]].<ref name="Conven1890">[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties9.html "Convention Between Great Britain and China Relating to Sikkim and Tibet (1890)"], [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref> However, Tibet refused to recognise the boundaries drawn by these treaties{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}. British forces led by Sir [[Francis Younghusband]] [[British expedition to Tibet|entered Tibet in 1904]] and made a treaty with the Tibetans.<ref name="Conven1904">[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties10.html "Convention Between Great Britain and Tibet (1904)"], [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref> In 1907, Britain and Russia acknowledged Chinese "[[suzerainty]]" over Tibet.<ref name=anglorussian1907>[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties12.html Convention Between Great Britain and Russia (1907)] Article II, [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref>
British interest in the borderlands was renewed when the [[Qing]] government sent military forces to establish a Chinese administration in Tibet (1910–12). A British military expedition was sent into what is now [[Arunachal Pradesh]] and the [[North-East Frontier Agency]] was created to administer the area (1912). In 1912–13, this agency reached agreements with the tribal leaders who ruled the bulk of the region.<ref>See ''North East Frontier of India'' (1910 & 1911 editions).</ref> After the fall of the Qing dynasty in China, Tibet government at Lhasa expelled all Chinese forces and declared itself independent (1913),<ref name="Goldstein30-1">{{harvnb|Goldstein|1997|pp=30–31}}</ref><ref name="Dalai">[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/tibet/tibet1.html "Proclamation Issued by His Holiness the Dalai Lama XIII (1913)"], [http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html Tibet Justice Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310103457/http://www.tibetjustice.org/index.html |date=10 March 2009 }}. Retrieved 20 March 2009</ref> however, this was not accepted by the newly founded Republic of China.<ref>Smith, Warren W., "''Tibetan Nation''", pp. 182–183</ref>
==Conference== [[File:西姆拉会议.jpg|thumb|Tibetan, British and Chinese participants and [[Plenipotentiary|plenipotentiaries]] to the Simla Treaty in 1914]] In 1913, the British convoked a conference at [[Shimla|Simla]], India to discuss the issue of Tibet's status.<ref name="maxwell">Maxwell 1970</ref> The conference was attended by representatives of Britain, the newly founded [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]], and the Tibetan government at Lhasa.<ref name="Conven1914"/> The British plenipotentiary, Sir [[Henry McMahon (diplomat)|Henry McMahon]], introduced the plan of dividing Tibetan-inhabited areas into "inner Tibet" and "outer Tibet" and apply different policies.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} "Inner Tibet," which includes Tibetan-inhabited areas in Qinghai, Gansu, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces, would be under the jurisdiction of the Chinese government. "Outer Tibet," covering approximately the same area as the modern "[[Tibet Autonomous Region]]" would enjoy autonomy. A boundary between Tibet and British India, later called the [[McMahon Line]], was drawn on a map referred to in the treaty.<ref name="Sinha-1974-12"/>
The Tibetan Indian boundary was negotiated in Simla between representatives from Britain and Tibet privately, in the absence of the Chinese representative. During the Simla conference a map of the Tibetan Indian border was provided as an annexe to the proposed agreement.<ref name="Calvin"/><ref name="maxwell"/><ref name=Sinha group=lower-alpha/><ref name=globalsecurity group=lower-alpha>{{quote|The line was marked on a large-scale (eight miles to the inch) map. On a much smaller-scale map, which was used in the discussions of the Inner Tibet-Outer Tibet boundary, the McMahon-Tibetan boundary (which would become the McMahon Line) was shown as a sort of appendix to the boundary between Inner Tibet and China proper (see Map Six,below).|Barnard 1984.}}</ref>
The [[s:Simla Accord (1914)#Schedule|Schedule appended to the Accord]] contained further notes. For example, it was to be understood that "Tibet forms part of Chinese territory" and after the Tibetans selected a Dalai Lama, the Chinese government was to be notified and the Chinese commissioner in Lhasa would "formally communicate to His Holiness the titles consistent with his dignity, which have been conferred by the Chinese Government"; that the Tibetan government appointed all officers for "Outer Tibet", and that "Outer Tibet" was not to be represented in the Chinese Parliament or any such assembly.<ref name="Conven1914"/><ref name="Goldstein75">{{harvnb|Goldstein|1991|p=75}}.</ref>
Negotiations failed when China and Tibet could not agree over the Sino-Tibetan boundary.<ref>Shakya 1999, pg. 5</ref> After the Chinese plenipotentiary, Ivan Chen, withdrew from the convention, the British and Tibetan plenipotentiaries attached a note denying China any privileges under the agreement and signed it as a bilateral Accord.<ref name="Goldstein75"/> At the same time the British and Lochen Shatra signed a fresh set of trade Regulations to replace those of 1908.<ref name=TibHist136>McKay, Alex, ''The History of Tibet: The modern period: 1895–1959, the Encounter with modernity'', p. 136.</ref>
==Aftermath==
Simla was initially rejected by the Government of India as incompatible with the 1907 Anglo-Russian Convention. The official treaty record, C.U. Aitchison's ''A Collection of Treaties'', was published with a note stating that no binding agreement had been reached at Simla.<ref name="Lin">Lin, Hsiao-Ting, "[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03068376708731991 Boundary, sovereignty, and imagination: Reconsidering the frontier disputes between British India and Republican China, 1914–47]", ''The Journal of Imperial & Commonwealth History,'' September 2004, '''32''', (3).</ref> Since the condition (agreement with China) specified by the accord was not met, the Tibetan government didn't agree with the McMahon Line. <ref name="Shakya1999"/>
The Anglo-Russian Convention was renounced by Russia and Britain jointly in 1921,<ref>[http://www.freetibet.org/about/uk-relations-tibet UK relations with Tibet], [http://www.freetibet.org/contact Free Tibet Campaign]. Retrieved 20 March 2009. "... in 1917, the Communist Government in Russia repudiated all the international engagements of the tsars, ... in 1921, the 1907 Treaty was cancelled by agreement."</ref> but the McMahon Line was forgotten until 1935, when interest was revived by civil service officer [[Olaf Caroe]].<ref name="Guruswamy">Guruswamy, Mohan, [http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/jun/21spec.htm "The Battle for the Border"], ''Rediff'', 23 June 2003.</ref> The [[Survey of India]] published a map showing the McMahon Line as the official boundary in 1937.<ref name="Guruswamy"/> In 1938, the British published the Simla Convention in Aitchison's ''Treaties''.<ref name="Lin"/><ref>Banerji, Arun Kumar, "[http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=367249&catid=38 China, The British And Tawang]", ''The Statesman'', 24 April 2011.</ref> A volume published earlier was recalled from libraries and replaced with a volume that includes the Simla Convention together with an editor's note stating that Tibet and Britain, but not China, accepted the agreement as binding.<ref>[http://www.mssu.edu/projectsouthasia/history/primarydocs/Treaties/Tibet/Schedule1914.htm Schedule of the Simla Convention, 1914] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060912194623/http://www.mssu.edu/projectsouthasia/history/primarydocs/Treaties/Tibet/Schedule1914.htm |date=12 September 2006 }}</ref> The replacement volume has a false 1929 publication date.<ref name="Lin"/>
In April 1938, a small British force led by Captain G. S. Lightfoot arrived in Tawang and informed the monastery the district was now Indian territory.{{sfn|Goldstein|1991|p=307}} The Tibetan government protested and its authority was restored after Lightfoot's brief stay. The district remained in Tibetan hands until 1951.
In the late 1950s, the McMahon Line became a source of tension between China and India.<ref name=barnettnyt>Robert Barnett, ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/25/opinion/25barnett.html?hp Did Britain Just Sell Tibet?]'', [[The New York Times]], 24 November 2008</ref> China contends that Tibet was never an independent state and so it could not sign a treaty on behalf of China to delineate an international frontier.<ref>Kaiyan Homi Kaikobad ''Interpretation and Revision of International Boundary'', Cambridge University Press, 2007, {{ISBN|0-521-86912-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-86912-6}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=-rgZvL6WXFcC&pg=PA37#PPA37,M1 pp. 36–38]</ref> China and India fought the [[Sino-Indian War]] in 1962, which nevertheless preserved the [[status quo ante bellum]]. Australian journalist and historian Neville Maxwell exposed a top-secret Indian war report that harshly criticised the highest echelons of power in India at the time for pursuing a flawed strategy of provoking China into the war without the means to handle a backlash. The so-called Henderson Brooks-Bhagat Report was an operational review of India's military debacle commissioned by New Delhi that Maxwell managed to obtain. Compiled by Lieutenant-General Henderson Brooks and Brigadier Premindra Singh Bhagat in 1963, it has been kept secret by the Indian government despite repeated appeals that it be declassified. <ref> {{Cite news| url=http://m.scmp.com/news/asia/article/1461099/neville-maxwells-revelation-reveals-india-was-hiding-nothing-over-its-1962 |title=Neville Maxwell discloses document revealing that India provoked China into 1962 border war |publisher=South China Morning Post|date=6 July 2017}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tibetinfonet.net/content/update/149|title=Border games. Rectifying an inconvenient history.|date=8 November 2009|accessdate=14 August 2010|agency=TibetInfoNet}}</ref> Years later, the area, then known as the [[North-East Frontier Agency]], gained Indian statehood as [[Arunachal Pradesh]].<ref>''China revives claims on Indian territory IRNA'', Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA No.035 05/04/2005 14:22) republished under the [http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/news/china/2005/china-050405-irna01.htm same name], [http://www.globalsecurity.org globalsecurity.org], <!--Retrieved 2009-04-11--></ref>
===2008 British policy change=== Until 2008 the British Government's position remained the same that China held [[suzerainty]] over Tibet but not full [[sovereignty]]. It was the only state still to hold this view.<ref name=economist-2008-11-24>Staff, ''[http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12570571 Britain's suzerain remedy]'', ''[[The Economist]]'', 6 November 2008</ref> [[David Miliband]], the British Foreign Secretary, described the old position as an [[anachronism]] originating in the geopolitics of the early 20th century.<ref>Lunn, p. 8</ref> Britain revised this view on 29 October 2008, when it recognised Chinese sovereignty over Tibet by issuing a statement on its website.<ref group=lower-alpha>[[David Miliband]], ''[http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/newsroom/latest-news/?view=PressS&id=8299838 Written Ministerial Statement on Tibet (29/10/2008)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202021442/http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/newsroom/latest-news/?view=PressS&id=8299838 |date=2 December 2008 }}'', Foreign Office website. Retrieved 25 November 2008. {{quote|Our ability to get our points across has sometimes been clouded by the position the UK took at the start of the 20th century on the status of Tibet, a position based on the geo-politics of the time. Our recognition of China's "special position" in Tibet developed from the outdated concept of suzerainty. Some have used this to cast doubt on the aims we are pursuing and to claim that we are denying Chinese sovereignty over a large part of its own territory. We have made clear to the Chinese Government, and publicly, that we do not support Tibetan independence. Like every other EU member state, and the United States, we regard Tibet as part of the People's Republic of China. Our interest is in long term stability, which can only be achieved through respect for human rights and greater autonomy for the Tibetans.|British Foreign Sectary}}</ref>''[[The Economist]]'' stated that although the British Foreign Office's website does not use the word sovereignty, officials at the Foreign Office said "it means that, as far as Britain is concerned, 'Tibet is part of China. Full stop.'"<ref name=economist-2008-11-24/>
The British Government sees their new stances as an updating of their position, while some others have viewed it as a major shift in the British position.<ref name=Lunn-7 group=lower-alpha>Lunn, p. 7 "However, in October 2008 there was what some have viewed as a major shift in the British position, although the Government sees it more as an updating of it. This involved abandoning the concept of 'Chinese suzerainty' on the grounds that it was unclear and out-dated."</ref> Tibetologist Robert Barnett thinks that the decision has wider implications. India's claim to a part of its north-east territories, for example, is largely based on the same agreements – notes exchanged during the Simla convention of 1914, which set the boundary between India and Tibet – that the British appear to have simply discarded.<ref name=barnettnyt/><ref name=barnettnyt/> It has been speculated that Britain's shift was made in exchange for China making greater contributions to the [[International Monetary Fund]].<ref name=barnettnyt/><ref>[http://www.spectator.co.uk/search/author/?searchString=James%20Forsyth Forsyth, James] (the web editor of ''[[The Spectator]]''). [http://www.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/3038881/have-brown-and-miliband-sold-out-tibet-for-chinese-cash.thtml Have Brown and Miliband sold out Tibet for Chinese cash?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203113429/http://www.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/3038881/have-brown-and-miliband-sold-out-tibet-for-chinese-cash.thtml |date=3 December 2008 }}, website of ''The Spectator'', 25 November 2008.</ref><ref>Editorial [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/telegraph-view/4969667/The-neglect-of-Tibet.html The neglect of Tibet], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 11 March 2009.</ref>

[[File:OldSuffolkCMaCourt.JPG|thumb|right|The [[John Adams Courthouse]] houses the Social Law Library]] The '''Social Law Library''', founded in 1803, is the second oldest [[law library]] in the [[United States]]. It is located in the [[John Adams Courthouse]] at [[Pemberton Square (Boston)|Pemberton Square]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], the same building which houses the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] and the [[Massachusetts Appeals Court]].
==History== The history of the library is very much bound up in the history of the Supreme Judicial Court itself. Many of the proprietors of the library were chief justices of the Supreme Judicial Court, including [[Theophilus Parsons]], [[Lemuel Shaw]], [[Horace Gray]], and [[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.]]. The library was also caught up in the debates between the [[Federalist Party (United States)|Federalists]], who wanted to see the [[common law]] (based on [[English law]]) received into the newly formed United States, and the [[Democratic-Republican Party (United States)|Jeffersonians]], who preferred to have a [[Civil law (legal system)|civil law]]-based system similar to the [[Napoleonic Code]]. The Federalists, who were prominent in Boston and integral to the library's founding, began importing English law books for local lawyers to use. The Supreme Judicial Court, needing a law library for their own use, permitted the library to be moved into the Court's offices in exchange for access to its many volumes. Meanwhile, the [[Massachusetts General Court]] (the state legislature of Massachusetts) established the office of [[Reporter of Decisions]], which was the first office of its kind at the state level in the United States, and the first officially reported decision was ''[[Gold v. Eddy]]'' (1804). This turn of events allowed the public greater access to the decisions of the courts of Massachusetts, and in turn popularized the [[common law]] legal system in the United States.
==Today== Today, many lawyers in the Boston area use the library for [[legal research]]. Members pay a yearly fee for the privilege of being admitted to the library and using its facilities, with the exception of state, court or non-profit legal services organizations members. The library has over 450,000 volumes of printed materials, most of which can be searched using an online catalog accessible via the library's web site.
==External links== * [http://www.socialaw.com/ Official homepage of the Social Law Library]

{{for|the earlier treaty|Treaty of Kyakhta (1727)}} {{history of Mongolia}} [[File:Mongolia 1915.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Mongolia in 1915]] Signed on 25 May 1915, the '''Treaty of Kyakhta''' was a tri-party treaty between [[Russian Empire|Russia]], [[Mongolia (1911–21)|Mongolia]], and [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|China]].
Russia and China recognized [[Outer Mongolia]]'s autonomy (as part of Chinese territory); Mongolia recognized China's suzerainty; Mongolia could not conclude international treaties with foreign countries regarding political and territorial questions.
The Mongolian representative, Prime Minister [[Tögs-Ochiryn Namnansüren]], was determined to stretch autonomy into [[de facto]] independence, and to deny the Chinese anything more than vague, ineffectual [[suzerain]] powers. The Chinese sought to minimize, if not to end, Mongolian autonomy. Mongolians viewed the treaty as a disaster because it denied the recognition of a truly independent, [[Pan-Mongolism|all-Mongolian state]]. Nevertheless, Outer Mongolia remained effectively outside Chinese control<ref>Batsaikhan, O. The Last King of Mongolia, Bogdo Jebtsundamba Khutuktu. Ulaanbaatar: Admon, 2008, p.290-293 - {{ISBN|978-99929-0-464-0}}</ref> and, according to explanation by baron B.E. Nolde, the Director of Law Section of the Russian Foreign Ministry, had all necessary attributes of the state in the international law of that time.<ref>[https://www.academia.edu/12779988/%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%B7%D1%8C%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD_%D0%A1.%D0%9B._2015._%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D0%9A%D1%8F%D1%85%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_1915_%D0%B3._%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D1%83_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%9C%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%B8_%D0%9A%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B5%D0%BC_Kuzmin_S.L._2015._%D0%A1entenary_of_the_Kyakhta_Agreement_of_1915_between_Russia_Mongolia_and_China_ Kuzmin, S.L. Сentenary of the Kyakhta Agreement of 1915 between Russia, Mongolia and China. – Asia and Africa Today (Moscow), 2015, no 4, p. 60-63]</ref>
[[File:中俄蒙协约签订现场.jpg|thumb|300px|Deputies of China, Russia and Outer Mongolia signing the Treaty of Kyakhta.]] The treaty severely curtailed the independent status of Mongolia declared in 1911, but eventually became moot after the [[October Revolution]] of 1917, and the declaration of the [[Mongolian People's Republic]] in 1921.
